author: By Rosa Lyster and Gueorgui Pinkhassov/Magnum, for The New York Times
title: My Accidental Visit to the Pandemic’s Party Capital
description: Kyiv was supposed to be a quick layover for the writer Rosa Lyster. But its underground nightlife turned out to be just what she needed.
content: My beginner’s guide to Kyiv: There is a courtyard in the old city with a beloved old raven living in it. Address: Reitarska Street, a three-block stretch full of restaurants and bars. Name of raven: Krum. Age: at least 25, which is apparently very old for a raven, although his age is not his defining characteristic. Defining characteristic: He is visited daily by a steady stream of people who intuitively understand that there is something special about the fact of this bird in this place, from little kids to hauntingly chic 22-year-olds to older ladies who adopt a particular stance when standing in the sunlight in front of a metal cage large enough to accommodate a panther — one hand on strap of bag, one hand on hip, head tilted interrogatively as they peer into the shadows in an effort to make meaningful eye contact with this large, elderly bird. Explanation as to the meaning of this whole scene: unavailable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: It’s All or Nothing for These Democrats, Even if That Means Biden Fails
description: The moderates’ immodest demands threaten the president’s agenda.
content: If President Biden’s “Build Back Better” bill dies in Congress, it will be because moderate Democrats killed it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Gender Pronouns Are Changing. It’s Exhilarating.
description: Embrace “they” for “he” or “she.” Pronoun history is fluid.
content: The other day I had occasion to use the pronoun “they” in the new way, referring to a specific person. Not your grandfather’s singular “they” with its generic meaning — “A student can hand their paper in early if they want to” — but “they” as in, “Roberta wants a haircut, and they also want some highlights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy K. Smith
title: In Richard Powers’s New Novel, Hope for a Grieving Kid and Planet May Lurk in the Human Brain
description: The Pulitzer Prize winner’s latest novel, “Bewilderment,” features a widowed father whose troubled son is transformed by a novel neurofeedback therapy with profound implications for the human race.
content: BEWILDERMENTBy Richard Powers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Here’s how pandemic rules are shaping the U.N. gathering.
description: Unlike last year, when the session was fully virtual, more than 100 heads of state and government are planning to address the General Assembly in person.
content: Unlike in 2020, when the U.N. General Assembly session was conducted almost entirely virtually because of the pandemic, more than 100 world leaders and other high-ranking representatives intend to deliver their speeches in person this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Australia’s Submarines Make Waves in Asia Long Before They Go to Sea
description: Some nations fear an accelerated arms buildup in a region where larger countries have already ramped up their military spending or capabilities.
content: China is swelling into a military superpower. India, Vietnam and Singapore are spending more on defense. Japan is leaning to do the same. Now Australia, backed by the United States and Britain, has catapulted the military contest with Beijing in Asia into a tense new phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Where Are the Tests?
description: Other countries are awash in Covid tests. The U.S. is not.
content: Your daughter wakes up with a scratchy throat, and you can’t decide whether she should go to school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: We’re on the Precipice of a Post-Roe World
description: The historian Leslie Reagan puts Texas’ latest abortion law in perspective.
content: A few weeks ago, the Supreme Court let stand a Texas law creating a system of vigilante legal enforcement against anyone who participates in an abortion after the point of fetal cardiac activity. In effect, Texas’ law bans abortions after about six weeks, which is long before many women even know they’re pregnant. And soon the court will hear arguments on a Mississippi abortion ban that will give the justices the chance to overturn Roe v. Wade directly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: California is sued over its rule on solar power installers.
description: A trade group is fighting a restriction on who can install batteries on solar units. A state licensing official says recent actions may have had unintended consequences.
content: Fearing that growth in California’s solar power sector could grind to a halt, the association representing the industry has sued the state over new restrictions on who can install batteries on solar units.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Haitians deported from Del Rio say they feel mistreated and betrayed.
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The Haitian migrants had done well for themselves. Since leaving their country, many more than a decade ago, they had built lives in Chile, Brazil, Panama. They had homes and cars. They had stable jobs as bank tellers, welders, mine supervisors, gas station attendants.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The Haitian migrants had done well for themselves. Since leaving their country, many more than a decade ago, they had built lives in Chile, Brazil, Panama. They had homes and cars. They had stable jobs as bank tellers, welders, mine supervisors, gas station attendants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Woke Words With John McWhorter, a Times Virtual Event
description: Join the writer and linguist on Oct. 14 for an evening of conversation and song, examining the words we continue to grapple with.
content: In any conversation about race in America, or any public debate, words matter. How do we describe what’s happening? How do we articulate what we think is right? What words do we avoid using and why?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kacey Musgraves, Country Music Chameleon
description: The singer and songwriter’s “Star-Crossed” documents the end of her marriage. But reports of her divorce from Nashville have been greatly exaggerated.
content: Kacey Musgraves’s new album, “Star-Crossed,” documents the collapse of the marriage she celebrated on her last album, the Grammy-winning “Golden Hour.” It’s an LP that calls back to her earliest, more modest-scaled work — the embodiment of post-exuberance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: New York’s Superstar Progressive Isn’t A.O.C.
description: Ritchie Torres isn’t a household name. He should be.
content: Ritchie Torres, a congressman from America’s poorest district — New York’s 15th, in the Bronx — quietly bristles at the A.O.C. comparison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Construction workers in Melbourne protest mandatory vaccinations.
description: A second straight day of demonstrations included violent clashes with the police.
content: Construction workers in Melbourne, Australia, clashed violently with the police for the second day in a row on Tuesday in a dispute over mandatory vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Eric Adams, N.Y.C.’s likely next mayor, wants to turn shuttered hotels into permanent housing for the homeless.
description: Thousands of rooms in hotels shuttered by the coronavirus pandemic would become “supportive housing” under a plan announced by New York’s likely next mayor.
content: Hotels in New York City that have been left empty by the pandemic would be converted into “supportive housing” that provides assistance to people struggling with mental illness or substance abuse and to people leaving the prison system, under a plan proposed on Monday by Eric Adams, who is likely to be the city’s next mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Nicole Hong
title: Google to Spend $2.1 Billion on Manhattan Office Building
description: The technology giant has built a sprawling campus on the West Side of Manhattan and has 12,000 employees in the city.
content: Google announced on Tuesday that it would spend $2.1 billion to buy a sprawling Manhattan office building on the Hudson River waterfront, paying one of the largest prices in recent years for an office building in the United States and providing a jolt of optimism to a real estate industry lashed by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Not Make the Kids Alright?
description: Spending more on children is a very good idea.
content: Americans love rags-to-riches stories, tales of people who transcended childhood poverty to achieve adult success. Unless you’re totally oblivious to reality, however, you surely realize that such stories are the exceptions, not the rule. The disadvantages of growing up in poverty — poor nutrition, poor health care, an impoverished environment, the cognitive burden that goes along with never having enough money — can and often do hobble children for the rest of their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Extremely Weird Politics of Covid
description: We need to acknowledge that it’s strange where right and left have ended up.
content: I want to put a text before you, from February 2020, the ideological landscape into which the coronavirus first arrived. It’s a review in The London Review of Books, a fine highbrow left-of-center publication, covering a book about plague and quarantine in 17th-century Italy. The book, by the University of London historian, John Henderson, details the attempts by the city of Florence — led by its public health board, the Sanità — to avoid the awful fate of other Italian cities: first by closing the city to commerce and then by imposing quarantines, lockdowns and what we now call social distancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: An extra J. & J. shot substantially boosts protection against Covid, the company reports.
description: Since the company received emergency authorization in February, 14.6 million people in the United States have received its one-shot vaccine.
content: A second dose of Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine substantially increased its protection against Covid-19, the company announced Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: London, Fashion and the Importance of Being … Something
description: There’s a sense of rebirth as physical shows return (and digital showcases come of age) in an uncertain new era.
content: LONDON — At first glance, it looked like it was back to business at London Fashion Week. A vast industrial show space was heaving on Friday, packed with public relations types and security guards in headsets, glowing floor-to-ceiling screens blasting social content (the venue was sponsored by TikTok) and tightly packed rows of fashion glitterati.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: AutoNation names Mike Manley as its chief executive, replacing Mike Jackson.
description: The former chief executive of Fiat Chrysler, Mr. Manley will start at the automotive retail giant on Nov. 1.
content: AutoNation, the automotive retail giant, has named Mike Manley, the former chief executive of Fiat Chrysler, as its chief executive, replacing Mike Jackson, who is retiring after running the company for most of the last 22 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Saadi Yacef, ‘Battle of Algiers’ Catalyst and Actor, Dies at 93
description: At the center of the Algerian effort to throw off French rule, he re-created that role in Gillo Pontecorvo’s searing 1966 movie, based on a book by Mr. Yacef.
content: Saadi Yacef, a revolutionary leader who fought French rule in Algeria in the 1950s and then set in motion — and acted in — “The Battle of Algiers,” Gillo Pontecorvo’s acclaimed 1966 film about the long anti-colonialism struggle, died on Sept. 10 in Algiers, the capital. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: United Nations, Haiti, Google: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Brara and Melody Melamed
title: For a New Generation of Woodworkers, Form Follows Function
description: In response to the colorful, zanier side of modern furniture, some American craftspeople are returning to elemental, straightforward and handmade pieces.
content: “IF A CHAIR or a building is not functional, if it appears to be only art, it is ridiculous,” wrote the American artist and furniture maker Donald Judd in his 1993 essay “It’s Hard to Find a Good Lamp.” In the piece, he derides most commercially available furniture — too overstuffed, too bourgeois, too obsessed with the past — and explains why, in the early ’70s, he felt compelled to design his own objects, first to fill his homes in Marfa, Texas, and Manhattan, and later to sell. According to Judd, while art is conceived to exist purely on its own terms, a chair is to be sat upon; its form should “never violate” that function.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alida Becker
title: Back to the Future, With Books Instead of a DeLorean
description: Three new historical novels remind us how what happened in days, and centuries, gone by connects to the world today.
content: Do you read historical fiction to be immersed in an alternate reality? To imagine what past lives might have looked and felt like? To find connections to the present? Your answers to those questions will determine your reaction to THE WOMEN OF TROY (Doubleday, 304 pp., $28), the latest installment in Pat Barker’s feminist retelling of the “Iliad.” Narrated, like its predecessor, “The Silence of the Girls,” by Briseis, a captive Trojan queen, it’s set in the camp of the increasingly fractious Greeks, trapped after their victory by a ferocious wind that prevents them from returning home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Duterte accuses rich countries of hoarding Covid vaccines while the poor ‘wait for trickles.’
description: “There is a man-made drought of vaccines ravaging poor countries,” the Philippines leader told the U.N. General Assembly in prerecorded remarks.
content: With his country badly lagging in Covid vaccinations, President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines railed against the world’s affluent countries at the United Nations on Tuesday, accusing them of hoarding vaccines while the poor “wait for trickles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: In Spain, Abortions Are Legal, but Many Doctors Refuse to Perform Them
description: Many physicians in the country call themselves “conscientious objectors” and deny the procedures, often forcing women to travel long distances for one.
content: ZARAGOZA, Spain — Dr. Mercedes Sobreviela, a gynecologist in this city in northeast Spain, believes it is a woman’s choice whether she has an abortion. She says the “right decision” for a woman is “always the one she wants.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Brockman
title: Specialty Pharmacies Cater to the Blind and Those With Impaired Vision
description: The pandemic has exposed flaws in services for people who can’t easily access a drive-through window for Covid shots or testing or can’t read prescription labels.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump Campaign Knew Lawyers’ Voting Machine Claims Were Baseless, Memo Shows
description: Days before lawyers allied with Donald Trump gave a news conference promoting election conspiracy theories, his campaign had determined that many of those claims were false, court filings reveal.
content: Two weeks after the 2020 election, a team of lawyers closely allied with Donald J. Trump held a widely watched news conference at the Republican Party’s headquarters in Washington. At the event, they laid out a bizarre conspiracy theory claiming that a voting machine company had worked with an election software firm, the financier George Soros and Venezuela to steal the presidential contest from Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Does My Mask Protect Me if Nobody Else Is Wearing One?
description: Masks work best when everyone in the room has one on, but you’ll still benefit from masking up even when those around you aren’t.
content: If I’m the only person wearing a mask in a store or other indoor location, am I really protected from infection?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Rick Gladstone
title: In his U.N. debut, Biden calls for global unity against common threats.
description: His efforts to move the United States past President Donald J. Trump’s more confrontational policies come amid growing frustration among allies with his administration’s approach.
content: President Biden delivered his debut address to the annual gathering of world leaders at the United Nations on Tuesday amid strong new doubts about his ability to vault the United States back into a position of global leadership after his predecessor’s promotion of “America First” isolationism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Justin Trudeau will remain prime minister, Canadian TV projects.
description: Canadian broadcasters forecast that Mr. Trudeau’s Liberal Party will only hold a minority of seats in the next Parliament, similar to results in 2019.
content: Justin Trudeau will remain Canada’s prime minister following the vote in an early election on Monday, Canadian broadcasters projected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gao
title: Yaya DaCosta Joins Elite Society in ‘Our Kind of People’
description: In an interview, the actor discusses leaving “Chicago Med” for her soapy new Fox drama about a powerful Black community on Martha’s Vineyard. “I can carry a show,” she said. “It’s time.”
content: After six seasons playing the nurse April Sexton on the hit NBC medical drama “Chicago Med,” Yaya DaCosta was contemplating her future in the “Chicago” franchise earlier this spring when she received an auspicious offer. She was given the opportunity to lead Fox’s “Our Kind of People,” a soapy new drama centering on the rich and powerful Black elite in Oak Bluffs on Martha’s Vineyard, and she was ready for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: House Democrats introduced the ‘Protecting Our Democracy Act.’
description: The broad package of new curbs to executive power is a response to numerous norms of self-restraint that former President Donald J. Trump violated.
content: House Democratic leaders introduced on Tuesday a much-anticipated package of proposed new limits on executive power, launching a post-Trump push to strengthen checks on the presidency that they hope will compare to the overhauls that followed the Watergate scandal and the Vietnam War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: How Humans Lost Their Tails
description: A new study suggests that a single genetic mutation helps explain why monkeys have tails, while apes and people do not.
content: For half a billion years or so, our ancestors sprouted tails. As fish, they used their tails to swim through the Cambrian seas. Much later, when they evolved into primates, their tails helped them stay balanced as they raced from branch to branch through Eocene jungles. But then, roughly 25 million years ago, the tails disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: 4 Takeaways From the Canadian Election
description: A vote few Canadians wanted took the country back to 2019.
content: Over the past few weeks, analysts and political advisers have repeatedly told me that Monday’s vote, which cost 600 million Canadian dollars to hold, would produce a Parliament that looked pretty much like the one Prime Minister Justin Trudeau dissolved in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Stengel
title: Two of America’s Leading Historians Look at the Nation’s Founding Once Again — to Understand It in All Its Complexity
description: Joseph J. Ellis’s “The Cause” and Gordon S. Wood’s “Power and Liberty” argue that the Constitution was a necessary compromise.
content: THE CAUSEThe American Revolution and Its DiscontentsBy Joseph J. EllisPOWER AND LIBERTYConstitutionalism in the American RevolutionBy Gordon S. Wood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Ayala
title: The Fight Over Abortion Rights in Mexico Isn’t Over
description: The Mexican Supreme Court's decision followed years of feminist activism.
content: Growing up in the 1990s in a Catholic household outside of Mexico’s capital, Mexico City, I learned as a young girl that abortion was out of the question. When I reached my adolescent years, the only representation I had ever seen of abortion in pop culture was in the film “The Crime of Padre Amaro.” In the movie, the priest impregnates a young woman, then takes her to an unsanitary and illegal clinic. The abortion goes wrong; she dies. The message landed: I was sure that having an abortion would lead to death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Shrink Facebook to Save the World
description: Facebook has been used as a tool for violence and abuse in country after country. Maybe it shouldn’t be everywhere.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Sanctuary City,’ Slamming the Door on the Dream
description: For the undocumented immigrant teenagers in Martyna Majok’s unsparing, unsentimental new play, home is a heartbreaking lesson in betrayal.
content: American playwrights typically stake out a territory and stick to it. Tennessee Williams, having adopted that name, became the poet of the ghostly, ghastly South. August Wilson was the bard of striving Black Pittsburgh. Edward Albee lurked like an imp inside the brain (or perhaps the cirrhotic liver) of the warped New England WASP aristocracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Worried About Your Teen on Social Media? Here’s How to Help.
description: For kids, developing a healthier relationship with Instagram and other platforms can be tricky.
content: The Wall Street Journal revealed last week that researchers at Instagram had studied for years how its photo-sharing app affects young users and found that it can be particularly harmful to teenage girls, news that alarmed parents and lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Heffernan
title: The Alarming Rise of Peter Thiel, Tech Mogul and Political Provocateur
description: In a revealing new biography, “The Contrarian,” the journalist Max Chafkin charts Thiel’s ascendancy in Silicon Valley and Washington, D.C., as a driven man drawn to far-right causes and beliefs.
content: THE CONTRARIAN Peter Thiel and Silicon Valley’s Pursuit of PowerBy Max Chafkin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Teenager Pleads Guilty in the Killing of Tessa Majors
description: Ms. Majors, a Barnard College student, was stabbed to death in 2019 in a killing that rattled New York City. One of her killers pleaded guilty on Tuesday.
content: When Tessa Majors, an 18-year-old Barnard College student, was found murdered in Morningside Park in 2019, New York City responded with shock and grief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau Projected to Remain Prime Minister, but Falls Short of a Majority
description: Voters denied him the expanded bloc of power he had been seeking in Parliament, unofficial results showed.
content: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s political gamble failed to pay off Monday when Canadian voters returned him to office but denied him the expanded bloc of power he had been seeking in Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Rick Gladstone
title: Biden vows to double aid on climate change, one of the key issues facing leaders.
description: The pledge, which depends on congressional approval, is considered key to the success of the U.N.-led climate talks that are planned for November in Glasgow.
content: President Biden said on Tuesday that his administration would seek to double aid aimed at helping developing nations address climate change, raising a pledge he made in April to about $11.4 billion a year by 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Baking That’s Simple, but Always Satisfying
description: In her new monthly column, Genevieve Ko shares easy, streamlined recipes, like handmade crisps and cookies, so you can feed your loved ones (and yourself) effortlessly.
content: The first time I made cookies on my own (peanut butter, at age 8), I knew I wanted to keep baking. I just had to figure out how.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Their Baby Died in the Hospital. Then Came the $257,000 Bill.
description: A New York family had good health insurance. But the bills for their daughter’s care started showing up and kept coming.
content: Brittany Giroux Lane gave birth to her daughter, Alexandra, a few days before Christmas in 2018. The baby had dark eyes and longish legs. She had also arrived about 13 weeks early, and weighed just two pounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
title: Trudeau Wins, but Is Diminished by a Futile Election
description: The prime minister struggled to find a campaign issue that could distinguish his party and expand its power in Parliament.
content: OTTAWA — One day after an election Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called a “pivotal moment” in his country’s history, Canada seems to have pivoted right back where it started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Food Scholar, Folk Singer, Blunt Speaker: The Many Lives of Leni Sorensen
description: An irreverent historian who gets her hands into traditional cooking, farming and crafts is finally, at 79, winning fame with Netflix’s “High on the Hog.”
content: CROZET, Va. — You pick up a lot of skills after 79 years of being Leni Sorensen, perhaps America’s most unsung food historian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Homeland Security investigates border patrol’s treatment of Haitian immigrants.
description: Photos and video have emerged showing agents chasing and grabbing immigrants while on horseback.
content: Images and video of U.S. Border Patrol agents on horseback grabbing and chasing down Haitian migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border have prompted the Department of Homeland Security to launch an investigation into the matter, the agency said on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Theater in a California Canyon Becomes an Oasis Once Again
description: Created by blacklisted actors during the Red Scare, Will Geer’s Theatricum Botanicum, a picturesque outdoor theater, is drawing audiences in the pandemic.
content: TOPANGA, Calif. — There were no famous names in the cast. It was the first staged professional production by a little-known playwright. And the theater was deep in the canyons of the Santa Monica Mountains, up a long windy road, midway between the beaches of the Pacific Ocean and the San Fernando Valley, a secluded bohemian outpost known for its artists, musicians and rattlesnakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: A top European official calls for a ‘pause and reset’ in the U.S. relationship.
description: An E.U. Commissioner said that “something is broken in our trans-Atlantic relations,” as other European officials question Washington’s motives after its submarine deal with Australia.
content: A top European Union official made a plea on Tuesday to “pause and reset” the relationship between the bloc and the United States as a diplomatic spat between France and the Biden administration has become a European issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: David Alan Grier on Navigating the Art World as a Black Collector
description: The Tony-nominated actor and comedian discusses his love for overalls, citrus trees and trying to sell his teenage daughter on Frank Sinatra.
content: David Alan Grier is riveted by jack rabbits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Mooallem and Meron Menghistab
title: I Had a Chance to Travel Anywhere. Why Did I Pick Spokane?
description: After 18 months of pandemic parenting isolation, the writer Jon Mooallem knew just where the cure might lie: a minor-league baseball game in eastern Washington.
content: By the time I pulled into Spokane, I was furious at myself for coming to Spokane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Frieden
title: I Ran the C.D.C. Here’s How to Prove That Americans Are Vaccinated.
description: By issuing Covid-19 vaccination verification guidelines, the federal government can help verifiers ensure that mandates are effective.
content: This month, President Biden announced a comprehensive plan to reinvigorate America’s fight against the Covid-19 pandemic. A big part of this plan hinges on mandating the vaccination of millions of federal workers. Employees of companies with more than 100 staff members will have to provide proof of vaccination or test negative for the coronavirus at least once a week. The businesses and other institutions that must enforce these mandates will have to verify vaccination status and test results to make this system work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: China’s Leaders Are Having Fun With Us. Who Can Blame Them?
description: We need a better strategy to counter China than submarines. Biden should get back into the TPP trade deal.
content: Anyone who says that China’s President Xi Jinping does not have a sense of humor is definitely not following the news from the Pacific these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Family of British Teen Reaches Settlement With U.S. Diplomat After Fatal Car Accident
description: Anne Sacoolas was charged in the death of 19-year-old Harry Dunn in 2019, while she was a State Department employee. The police said she had been driving on the wrong side of the road.
content: LONDON — The family of a 19-year-old British motorcyclist has reached a resolution with the U.S. State Department employee who fatally struck him with her car two years ago, the latest development in a case that touched off diplomatic tensions between Britain and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zlata Kozul Naumovski
title: The Suburbs Beckoned, but They Found a Way to Stay in the City
description: When the rowhouse next door came on the market, one couple decided to remain in Washington, D.C., and merge the two houses. It wasn’t easy — or cheap.
content: For Ralph and Shamita Etienne-Cummings, the suburbs have long held a certain allure — especially since 2010, when their son, Blaze, was born and Mr. Etienne-Cummings’s mother moved into their 1876 rowhouse in Washington, D.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Stella Tan, Lynsea Garrison, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: A ‘Righteous Strike’
description: Inside the Times investigation that forced the U.S. military to acknowledge that a drone attack in Afghanistan was a deadly error.
content: When he visited the site of an American drone strike in a densely packed neighborhood of Kabul, the Afghan capital, Matthieu Aikins, a Times journalist, knew something wasn’t adding up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: After 92 years, Fortune will have its first female editor in chief.
description: Alyson Shontell, 35, will be in charge of content across Fortune’s magazine and website, as well as its conferences, newsletters, videos and podcasts.
content: Fortune on Tuesday named Alyson Shontell as its new editor in chief, the first woman to hold the role in its 92-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My Body Told a Different Story’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: The day my 80-year-old mother announced she was moving to my town for the rest of her life, I was so shaken, I couldn’t remember how to set the table. Three thousand miles separated us for a reason. She had betrayed and refused to support me at the worst moment of my life. Two decades later, she and her dementia arrived, challenging me to cross a chasm of ambivalence and distrust so I could become the daughter she needed. Her decline pushed every button I had, but before she died, my rusty, wounded heart cracked open. — Laura Davis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cao Li
title: Default expectations for China Evergrande rise as a payment deadline looms.
description: The chairman of the troubled Chinese real estate giant, predicted a turnaround, but a new report predicted Beijing may have to step in if a collapse poses a risk to the economy.
content: Shares of China Evergrande, the troubled real estate giant whose fate has contributed to jitters in global markets, fell again on Tuesday amid a new prediction that it would soon default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Lena Waithe, Gillian Flynn to Start Book Imprints
description: The two women are joining Zando, an independent publishing company founded last year that plans to work with authors and sell books in unconventional ways.
content: When Gillian Flynn submitted her novel “Gone Girl” to her publisher, Crown, she wasn’t sure what executives would make of the story’s twists and its churlish, unreliable female narrator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Black Surfers Reclaim Their Place on the Waves’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the history of Black surfers and the actions they are taking against racism.
content: Featured Article: “Black Surfers Reclaim Their Place On the Waves” by Diane Cardwell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Dougher
title: I Had My First Child at 45. Here’s What I Learned.
description: A little empathy goes a long way, and people are going to judge.
content: The first time a stranger mistook me for the grandmother of my own child, I was in an airport, hauling my 2-year-old to a connecting flight. I was purchasing a bottle of water; the baby was having a tantrum. I put her on the floor to let her shriek and calmly made my purchase. The clerk gave me a sororal smile and said: “Grandchildren are a handful, that’s for sure. I’ve got four of my own!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Laments Cricket Matches Unplayed, and Blames Politics
description: Many see the pullouts by the England and New Zealand teams as punishment for the country’s support of the Afghan Taliban.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The English men’s and women’s cricket teams have abruptly canceled plans to play in Pakistan next month, the second international withdrawal for a country both obsessed with the sport and increasingly worried about its image on the world stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Veterans discharged under ‘don’t ask, don’t tell’ may be eligible for full V.A. benefits.
description: The new guidance comes on the 10th anniversary of the policy’s repeal.
content: Veterans who were discharged from the military under the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy may be eligible for full benefits from the Department of Veterans Affairs under new guidance issued on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Jibs, Seafood Served With a River View, to Open in Hudson Yards
description: Barbecue in Koreatown, a mini food hall featuring Asian snacks in Williamsburg, and more restaurant news.
content: With the vibe of a seafood shack but far grander, this outdoor newcomer to Hudson Yards, overlooking the river, seats 200 at a bar area with counters and high-tops, and on a dining deck with captain’s chairs and picnic tables. It will be a year-round affair, with a roof covering that retracts, removable side panels and heaters. The owners, Cobi Levy, Will Makris and Thatcher Shultz, hauled in a couple of shipping containers for the kitchen and bar, covered them with shingles and strung them with used buoys for which they spent months scavenging local shorefront dealers. The chef, David Ladner, who worked in Rhode Island and Cambridge, Mass., has an extensive menu of seafood specialties, including raw bar items, baked clams, steamed mussels, fish and chips, grilled black sea bass, grilled lobster, lobster rolls two ways, and lobster grilled cheese. A hot dog, cheeseburger, chicken fingers, salads, mac and cheese, and a number of vegetable preparations round out the choices. There’s a blueberry buckle for dessert and a full bar. All the seafood is listed with its geographic source. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Bradley
title: Candles That Are More Like Ephemeral Sculptures
description: A new crop of options stress form, color and process, and are sure to brighten up your space in more ways than one.
content: In the 2010s, when homes began to double as backdrops for social media posts, the branded candle, or evidence thereof, became ubiquitous. Maybe it was a Le Labo Santal 26 burning serenely alongside a neat stack of fashion books. Maybe it was an already-spent Diptyque variety, the empty glass holder now filled with makeup brushes and perched on the corner of a bathroom sink. Now modern classics, these candles are still around, and still smell as good as ever, but there’s a newer crop of options that are, well, weirder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: At U.N., Biden Calls for Diplomacy, Not Conflict, but Some Are Skeptical
description: The president said he wants global cooperation to meet challenges, but some allies and adversaries say his actions point to confrontation with China and unilateral action, belying his words.
content: President Biden, fighting mounting doubts among America’s allies about his commitment to working with them, used his debut address to the United Nations on Tuesday to call for “relentless diplomacy” on climate change, the pandemic and efforts to blunt the expanding influence of autocratic nations like China and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: BTS Took Center Stage at the U.N. Over One Million Fans Watched Live.
description: The boy band’s seven members accompanied President Moon Jae-in of South Korea, who designated them as special presidential envoy for future generations and culture.
content: Amid the clutches of a pandemic, the conflict in Afghanistan and deadly storms exacerbated by climate change, more than one million people were transfixed by the United Nations on Monday. Not to watch a head of state, but rather a boy band: BTS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: C.I.A. Officer Suffers Havana Syndrome Symptoms
description: The officer, who had been traveling in India with the agency’s director, was given medical attention after an unexplained incident triggered injuries.
content: WASHINGTON — An intelligence officer traveling in India this month with the C.I.A. director reported symptoms consistent with the so-called Havana syndrome, signaling a possible escalation in the mysterious incidents that have affected American officials since 2016, current and former officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: Evergrande Crisis Shows Cracks in China’s Property Market
description: Experts are making increasingly grim predictions about the developer’s ability to hold on without a government bailout, and the consequences of a possible collapse.
content: Angry home buyers are waiting on as many as 1.6 million apartments to be completed. Suppliers of cement, paint and rebar are owed more than $100 billion in payments. Workers  are panicking that loans they made to their employer cannot be repaid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden faces an uphill climb as he tries to reassure allies at the U.N. General Assembly.
description: In conversations over the past two weeks, allies say they have new concerns about the United States.
content: At the beginning of the summer, President Biden’s aides had every reason to believe the opening of the U.N. General Assembly, the annual diplomatic Super Bowl of self-congratulatory speeches and closed-door meetings, would be a pretty glorious moment. After all, he wasn’t Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Endangered African Penguins, With Multiple Bee Stings, Are Found Dead
description: Dead bees were found near where the birds died at a park in South Africa, said officials, who suggested the bees may have become aggressive after their nest was disturbed.
content: More than 60 endangered African penguins were recently found dead, all with multiple bee stings and no other external injuries, according to officials in a coastal city in South Africa where the birds regularly migrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Taliban Complete Interim Government, Still Without Women
description: The Taliban spurned calls from the United Nations and big donors to include women in its new cabinet, but did add a few men from minority ethnic groups.
content: The Taliban refused to bow to the demands of the United Nations and the international community to include women in their cabinet, announcing the completion of an interim government with a lineup that was entirely male and kept members of the Taliban’s old guard in the top echelon of the leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: The Roots of French Pique
description: France was right to be angry about the submarine deal. But it'll get over it.
content: It’s hardly surprising that France would be furious over losing a multibillion-dollar arms deal with Australia, all the more so because it believes it was blindsided as Canberra, Washington and London secretly worked to get a different deal for themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Clamping Down on ‘Spiritual Opium’
description: Chinese tech regulation, Elizabeth Holmes’s trial and Facebook’s obfuscation.
content: You’d think the biggest story in tech to watch right now is the increasing power of the giant U.S. tech firms — and how to regulate them (regulation will come, at some point). But I can’t stop paying attention to what’s happening to China’s enormous tech industry and the entrepreneurial leaders who built it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Uneven Global Vaccination Threatens Economic Rebound, O.E.C.D. Warns
description: The group forecast that the worldwide economy would grow 5.7 percent in 2021, slightly lower than its previous estimate.
content: PARIS — A global recovery from the pandemic is finally taking hold as rising vaccination rates in advanced economies allow governments to keep businesses open and people to resume leading largely normal lives, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Unvaccinated and defiant, Bolsonaro pushes back against criticism in his U.N. speech.
description: Brazil’s far-right president, who bypassed the U.N. General Assembly’s vaccination requirement, was the first leader so speak, portraying his country as a success story portrayed unfairly by the media.
content: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil kicked off the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday by defending the use of ineffective drugs to treat the coronavirus and by pushing back on criticism of his government’s environmental record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Sarah Dash, the ‘Glue’ of the Vocal Trio Labelle, Is Dead at 76
description: She brought her church-rooted soprano and high harmonies to the rock and funk powerhouse best known for the No. 1 hit “Lady Marmalade.”
content: Sarah Dash, a founding member of the groundbreaking, million-selling vocal trio Labelle, died on Monday. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: No-Win Situations?
description: Daniel Okulitch makes a case for more puns.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Daniel Okulitch, the 64th constructor to debut in the New York Times Crossword this year! This puzzle is packed with some good old-fashioned puns that solvers are sure to enjoy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: With Each Change, Their Love Continued to Grow
description: Joseph Schneier had spent the last year transitioning when he met Allie Brashears. More challenges (and a pandemic) came after their 2018 wedding, but so did an outdoor fire pit.
content: When Joseph Schneier posted his profile on the dating app OkCupid in 2016, he didn’t think anyone would respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Lil Nas X Reveals Himself on ‘Montero’
description: After a record-breaking single, a tentative EP, a public coming out and another newsworthy smash, the 22-year-old pop sensation offers a fuller view of his inner world.
content: Lil Nas X, the gleefully queer 22-year-old pop star and savvy digital trickster, often cuts an impossibly confident figure in public. Red carpets and awards show stages have lately become international showcases for his impishly androgynous imagination. On social media — his own personal amusement park — his deft retorts to purer-than-thou pearl-clutchers and homophobic haters seem so effortless, they prompt a modern philosophical question: What’s the sound of one hand clapping back?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel
title: No More Apologies: Inside Facebook’s Push to Defend Its Image
description: Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, has signed off on an effort to show users pro-Facebook stories and to distance himself from scandals.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, signed off last month on a new initiative code-named Project Amplify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: John Nkengasong, of the Africa C.D.C., Will Lead PEPFAR
description: Dr. Nkengasong will be the first person of African origin to oversee the U.S. government program combating H.I.V., which has ravaged the continent.
content: The Biden administration plans to nominate John Nkengasong, a virologist and director of the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, to lead the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, according to several sources familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik and Cole Wilson
title: Bicycle Diaries: Cruising With the ‘American Utopia’ Family
description: Our intrepid reporter and photographer biked through Queens with David Byrne and some of his castmates ahead of their return to Broadway. Then the skies opened up.
content: On a dock in Queens, David Byrne’s musical bike gang was gearing up to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll
title: A Family, a Dream and a Season of Fear
description: Than Than Htwe and her husband moved to America in hopes of better opportunity for their son. They were greeted with violence instead.
content: They are small figures moving through a subway station on a Saturday in Manhattan — a mother and her son speaking softly to each other in Burmese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Yoffe
title: Anne-Marie Slaughter Explains What She Has Learned From a Long Career of Public Service
description: Slaughter’s “Renewal” looks at how a personal transformation can lead to broader social change.
content: RENEWAL
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Shukette Brings Modern Middle Eastern Cooking to Manhattan
description: Hot-from-the-oven breads, a charcoal grill and a market’s worth of fresh herbs and vegetables mark a new approach.
content: Shukette is the chef Ayesha J. Nurdjaja’s faster, looser, louder spinoff of Shuka. Both restaurants get their names from shuk, the Hebrew word for an open-air market, and Shukette gets more than that: the commotion and noise, the smell of cumin and charcoal, the head-spinning array of snacks and pickles and dips and skewers and hot disks of bread all evoke a Middle Eastern bazaar at full tilt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Nayeri
title: An Irreverent Novel Trains Its Gaze on Refugees and Their Rescuers
description: “The Wrong End of the Telescope,” by the Lebanese American writer Rabih Alameddine, examines the relationship between Middle Eastern refugees and their Western rescuers with clear eyes and trenchant humor.
content: THE WRONG END OF THE TELESCOPEBy Rabih Alameddine
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Apple iPhone 13 Review: The Most Incremental Upgrade Ever
description: The new iPhone is 10 percent faster than the last one, and the photos are slightly better. In a word: Huh.
content: The truth is that smartphones peaked a few years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Biden tries to reassure allies at the U.N.
content: President Biden delivered his first address to the annual gathering of world leaders at the U.N. in New York City amid strong doubts about his ability to restore U.S. global leadership after the Trump administration’s “America First” isolationism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: M.L.S. and Liga MX Fill a Hole In Soccer’s Schedule With Themselves
description: The Leagues Cup, part of an effort to capitalize on global interest in the game, will likely raise new concerns about soccer players’ exhausting schedules.
content: In a major reordering of soccer competition in North America, the top men’s leagues in the United States and Mexico announced Tuesday the creation of an annual World Cup-style tournament in which every team from both leagues will compete. The monthlong tournament will take place in July and August, beginning in 2023, expanding the collaboration between Major League Soccer and Liga MX and adding more matches to an already crowded world soccer calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: In California, Even Fire-Resistant Trees Need to Be Protected From Flames
description: Giant sequoias struggle to withstand the intensity of recent fires.
content: Somewhere between a childhood vacation to Sequoia National Park and a college biology class, I latched on to a single fact about California’s giant sequoias: They’re immune to wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: Beasts and Baseball: New Science Fiction and Fantasy
description: “The Body Scout,” “Light From Uncommon Stars” and “No Gods, No Monsters” tell stories of genetic dystopias, musical gifts and mythic creatures.
content: Lincoln Michel’s debut novel, THE BODY SCOUT (Orbit, 356 pp., $27), blends noir, cyberpunk and sports into something at once timeless and original. In an unsettlingly near-future New York where extreme climate change has made cybernetic limbs and genetic modifications — called “upgrades” — necessary and commonplace, steep income inequality and horrifying medical debt are ever more prevalent. But the book’s not really about those things. First and foremost, it’s about baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone and Farnaz Fassihi
title: The Taliban nominate a U.N. envoy, complicating a quandary for the General Assembly.
description: The move sets up a possible showdown with the current envoy, nominated only months ago by a government that has since collapsed.
content: The Taliban have nominated an ambassador to represent Afghanistan at the United Nations, U.N. officials said Tuesday, injecting a new twist into what was already a delicate diplomatic quandary in the global organization.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Painful Reminder of Baby’s Death: $257,000 Bill
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 21, 2021.
content: “For them, it’s just business, but for us it means constantly going through the trauma of reliving our daughter’s death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: He Nearly Qualified for Release From Rikers. Instead, He Died There.
description: Isaabdul Karim was being held on a parole violation when he died on Sunday, becoming the 11th person incarcerated at the jail to die this year.
content: When Gov. Kathy Hochul announced on Friday that nearly 200 people being held at the Rikers Island jail complex on minor parole violations would be immediately released, Isaabdul Karim was not on the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: What if ‘Star Wars’ Really Were Japanese?
description: “Star Wars: Visions,” a collection of short films on Disney+, lets Japanese animators play with a franchise that has deep roots in their country’s storytelling traditions.
content: “Intellectual property” probably wasn’t a term anyone thought to apply to “Star Wars” when the first movie premiered back in May 1977. More than 40 years of films, books, television series, toys, games, trading cards and theme park rides later, it’s hard to think of George Lucas’s outer-space saga as anything but.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Webinar: Personal Narratives From the Newsroom to the Classroom
description: Join us on Oct. 7 as a teacher and a New York Times editor share their perspectives on what makes a great personal narrative.
content: Building on our narrative-writing unit plan, this webinar will delve deeper into what makes a great personal narrative. You will hear from experts, including a New York Times editor who selects stirring personal stories for the popular Modern Love column, and a high school English teacher who uses our narrative-writing unit and mentor texts from The Times to help her students write college essays with voice, style and meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Who is speaking at the U.N. General Assembly, who isn’t — and why did Brazil go first?
description: Many leaders are taking advantage of the in-person platform, but others sent recorded video or had lower-ranking officials step in. Either way, in several cases that choice signals a message, too.
content: Several prominent leaders delivered in-person addresses at the U.N. General Assembly meeting on Tuesday, including President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, an avowed Covid skeptic whose mismanagement of the pandemic threatens his political future. Mr. Bolsonaro also created a stir by vowing to defy the meeting’s vaccination requirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Review: For Armory Recitals, a Modest but Memorable Return
description: Paul Appleby and Conor Hanick presented a song program focused on cycles by Beethoven and Berg.
content: The past few weeks have brought heartening signs that classical music is coming back to New York after the devastating pandemic closures of the past year and a half. The Metropolitan Opera reopened the doors for an inspiring performance of Verdi’s Requiem on Sept. 11. The New York Philharmonic inaugurated its new season last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: A Pandemic Space Race: Self-Storage Roars Back
description: Occupancy rates and rents are at record highs, drawing investors and entrepreneurs looking for growth opportunities.
content: Early in the pandemic, Katharine Lau, a commercial real estate professional, turned her focus to decluttering, and as she stared at a pile of unneeded things, she wondered how she could save them despite her lack of space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: How the Case of Gabrielle Petito Galvanized the Internet
description: The disappearance of a 22-year-old woman sparked national interest, in large part because of the online sleuthing of amateur detectives.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people are reported missing in the United States every year. But it’s rare for a single case to capture the public’s attention — and galvanize individuals to take action — as the disappearance of Gabrielle Petito has.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: An end to the U.S. travel ban.
content: Foreign travelers who provide proof of full vaccination against Covid-19 can enter the U.S. starting in November, easing tensions with Europe and reopening the country to thousands of people, including many who have been separated from family during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: Taking the ‘Shame Part’ Out of Female Anatomy
description: Anatomists have bid farewell to “pudendum,” but other questionable terms remain.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Does His Best Tucker Carlson Impersonation
description: Meyers mimicked the Fox News host on Monday night, saying Carlson could have a career in improv.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Week Into the School Year, the Mayor Makes Changes
description: There will be more testing and less quarantining as New York City pushes to keep its public schools open during Covid.
content: It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at Mayor Bill de Blasio’s changes on Covid-19 testing plans in schools and quarantine rules when students test positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cass R. Sunstein
title: A History of Medical Innovation That Doesn’t Ignore the Side Effects
description: In “You Bet Your Life,” Paul A. Offit looks at advances that have prolonged life, from chemotherapy to the Covid vaccine, and the difficult, even deadly, paths to arrive at them.
content: YOU BET YOUR LIFEFrom Blood Transfusions to Mass Vaccination, the Long and Risky History of Medical InnovationBy Paul A. Offit
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A gas station attendant is killed in Germany after telling a customer to mask up.
description: He was shot with an unlicensed weapon, in what appears to be the country’s first killing over coronavirus rules.
content: BERLIN — A 20-year-old student working at a gas station in southwestern Germany was shot and killed after refusing to sell beer to an unmasked customer, the local prosecutor said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Cora Engelbrecht
title: U.K. Police Charge 3rd Man in Effort to Kill Russian Dissident
description: The authorities added a suspect in the attempted assassination of Sergei V. Skripal in 2018. Separately, a European court blamed Russia for Alexander V. Litvinenko’s murder in 2006.
content: British counterterrorism police announced criminal charges against a senior Russian military intelligence officer on Tuesday for the attempted assassination of a former Russian spy who was poisoned in England in 2018 with a deadly nerve agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Broadway Show Would You Most Like to See?
description: The longest shutdown in Broadway history is over. Tell us shows you would love to see — whether they’re on now, or are a part of theater history.
content: Do you enjoy live theater? If so, do you like musicals best, or are you more a fan of plays? When was the last time you saw a theatrical performance live?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the Ryder Cup, Would 12 Divided by 3 Equal Victory for the U.S.?
description: In 2008, Paul Azinger led the United States to victory over Europe after dividing his team into three four-man “pods.” Would that system change the Americans’ luck this year?
content: “Pod” is not a golf word. And yet it has been on the tongue of nearly everyone in the golf community during the last, tense days before this week’s Ryder Cup, the biennial, pressure-packed team competition between American and European pro golfers that begins Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: California’s Wildfires Had an Invisible Impact: High Carbon Dioxide Emissions
description: From June to August, the blazes emitted far more planet-warming carbon dioxide than in any other summer in nearly two decades, satellite data shows.
content: This wildfire season so far in California has been extraordinary, producing thousands of fires — including one that, at nearly a million acres burned, is the largest single fire in state history — and spewing so much smoke that air quality has been affected thousands of miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Andrew E. Kramer and David E. Sanger
title: The Biden administration is combating ransomware with a crackdown on cryptocurrency payments.
description: Previewing its new approach, the Treasury Department announced sanctions against a virtual currency exchange called Suex.
content: The Biden administration took action on Tuesday to crack down on the growing problem of ransomware attacks, expanding its use of sanctions to cut off digital payment systems that have allowed such criminal activity to flourish and threaten national security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.32 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: When Sacred Ground Is Also Multimillion-Dollar Real Estate
description: What to do with the site of the collapsed condo in Surfside, Fla.? There is no easy way to both honor victims and compensate condo owners.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Unbearable grief absorbed Anabella Levine when Champlain Towers South collapsed in Florida this summer, burying her beloved older brother and three cousins in the rubble of her building while she was away for the night. Identifying some of the remains took an excruciating 18 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: J. & J. boosters.
content: Over the last few weeks, millions of people who have received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine have been in limbo as they wait for guidance about whether they’ll need booster shots — and to learn what protection, if any, an extra dose might offer. Today, they’re finally getting some clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Leslie Reagan
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Leslie Reagan. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Leslie Reagan. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Sudan Leaders Say They Thwarted Coup Attempt by Loyalists of Former Dictator
description: Government officials blamed the bid on supporters of longtime ruler Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who was overthrown in 2019 by a military takeover prompted by widespread popular protests.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Sudanese authorities said they thwarted an attempted coup by loyalists of the deposed dictator Omar Hassan al-Bashir on Tuesday, the latest sign of instability in an African nation battling persistent economic hardship under a fragile transitional government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Anthony Gose Completes Unusual Conversion, From Hitter to Pitcher
description: A former outfielder follows a path few others have taken, and does it throwing 100 miles per hour.
content: After his career as a major league outfielder wound down, Anthony Gose decided to give pitching a chance. The move seemed like a long shot, a bid to extend a career that was realistically probably over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Urges Supreme Court to Uphold Roe v. Wade
description: The department also sought permission to present oral arguments in December when the court hears a case challenging Mississippi’s restrictive abortion law.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court on Monday to reaffirm Roe v. Wade when it hears a case challenging Mississippi’s restrictive abortion law later this year, arguing that any other decision would uphold an unconstitutional law and undermine a doctrine that gives power to Supreme Court precedents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: Even the G-Spot is Named for a Man
description: Why do so many female body parts honor male scientists?
content: “Pudendum” isn’t the only questionable term slinking around in the female pelvis. Pull out a map to this region and you face an array of unfamiliar landmarks: Alcock’s canal, the pouch of Douglas, Bartholin’s glands, the fallopian tubes. These are all body parts named in honor of the people thought to have “discovered” them. They are relics from a time when the female body was considered terra incognita for great minds of medicine to explore, stake out and claim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham, Adam Liptak and J. David Goodman
title: Lawsuits Filed Against Texas Doctor Could Be Best Tests of Abortion Law
description: Legal experts said two lawsuits filed this week might test the constitutionality of the Texas law more than federal challenges by abortion providers and the Justice Department.
content: DALLAS — When the United States’ most restrictive abortion law went into effect in Texas on Sept. 1, it worked exactly as intended: It effectively stopped all abortions in the second-most populous state.

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: After Merce, the Dances Go On, and Go On to Inspire
description: “In Conversation With Merce,” a virtual program, features Merce Cunningham’s “Landrover” and responses to it, by Liz Gerring and Kyle Abraham.
content: When a choreographer dies, the survival of the work is always in peril. When Merce Cunningham died, in 2009, the risk felt especially acute. In the tradition of modern dance, the repository of any choreographer’s legacy has usually been a namesake company, but the legacy plan for Cunningham included the disbanding of his troupe, in 2011.

title: Democrats Begin Effort to Curb Post-Trump Presidential Powers
description: But to appeal to Republicans, a bill being introduced in the House to impose checks on executive authority may be broken into pieces in the Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — House Democrats are planning to introduce a package of proposed new limits on executive power on Tuesday, beginning a post-Trump push to strengthen checks on the presidency that they hope will compare to the overhauls that followed the Watergate scandal and the Vietnam War.

content: In a move designed to bolster Beijing’s climate credentials, President Xi Jinping of China said Tuesday that his country would stop building coal-burning power plants overseas, ending its support for construction projects that rely on the world’s dirtiest fossil fuel.

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: What a Fungus Reveals About the Space Program
description: One thing’s for sure: Escaping the dung heap doesn’t come cheap.
content: I spend a lot of time lately thinking about a fungus called Pilobolus. It lives on dung, mostly from cows and horses, happily munching away, enriching the soil as it goes, until it starts to run out of dung to eat. Then something magical happens: The fungus stops eating and rearranges itself into a giant stalk with a ball of cells — a sporangium — on top.

content: In August, a month or two after receiving his second Covid-19 vaccine shot, Pierpaolo Piccioli, the creative director of Valentino, posted a selfie on Instagram. In it, he was smiling on a beach in his hometown — Nettuno, Italy — wearing a black hoodie with the red Valentino “V” logo on the chest. Beneath it, instead of the brand name as usual, was the word “Vaccinated.”

author: By Jeneen Interlandi
title: We Have Gone Badly Off Track in the Global Covid Fight
description: The world can’t end this pandemic — or prevent the next one — without global vaccine equity.
content: The giant steel vats used to make most of the world’s vaccines are not easy to come by. They’re highly specialized pieces of equipment; there are only so many of them to go around, and it’s expensive and time-consuming to make more. So when vaccine developers were figuring out how to produce billions of Covid-19 vaccine shots as quickly as possible, they decided to use an alternative: disposable bioreactor bags. At first, it was a win-win. The bags are quicker and cheaper to make than the tanks, and using them can shave precious hours off manufacturing times because they don’t have to be cleaned and sterilized after each use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘The Right to Sex’ Thinks Beyond the Parameters of Consent
description: Amia Srinivasan’s brilliant essays urge us to think more fully about sex, as a personal experience with social implications.
content: Americans don’t think about sex nearly enough — this occurred to me after reading “The Right to Sex,” Amia Srinivasan’s quietly dazzling new essay collection. Talk about it, yes; argue over it, most definitely. But Srinivasan, a professor of social and political theory at Oxford, wants us to think more fully about sex, as a personal experience with social implications: “Sex, which we think of as the most private of acts, is in reality a public thing.”

content: Michaela Onyenwere’s W.N.B.A. career began with a celebration that spread across social media timelines and mentions. When the Liberty drafted her No. 6 overall in April, a video stream of her dancing grandmother took center stage. Theresa Duru wore traditional Nigerian apparel, including a head tie, called a gele, that billowed toward the ceiling like a cumulus cloud as she busted moves and turned heads. Duru became a meme and a tagline: “We’re all Grandma.”
